report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: The Zscaler ThreatLabz research team has recently discovered a malware campaign targeting users applying for Thailand travel passes. The end payload of many of these attacks is AsyncRAT, a Remote Access Trojan that can be used to monitor, control, and steal sensitive data from victims' machines.

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: Thailand Pass is an online travel agency that brokers airline tickets to travelers who want to visit Thailand or other foreign countries. Attackers trick victims using a spoof web page that poses as Thailand Pass, ultimately baiting users into downloading AsyncRAT.

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: The Thailand Pass organization has issued an advisory for these malicious campaigns on their official website "tp.consular[.]go[.]th" as shown below.

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: Figure 1: Advisory by Thailand pass organization.

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: In this blog, our team will provide a deep analysis of the malware campaign that we have observed related to these attacks.

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: The below image shows the complete flow of execution for this malware campaign.

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: Figure 2: Complete attack chain workflow.

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: The following malicious URLs were used for this campaign, as found through our Threat Intelligence collection framework.

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: hxxps://bit[.]ly/Thailand-passport - is an shortened URL of

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: hxxps://onedrive.live[.]com/Download?cid=6BCBE135551869F2&resid=6BCBE135551869F2!168&authkey=AGoYtbf1Lb5VjFg

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: On accessing the above URL, the page delivers a HTML file named Thailand Pass Registration System (for air travel.html. Once the user opens the HTML file, it automatically drops an ISO file named thailand_Passport.iso without any user interaction, as shown below.

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: Figure 3 : Thailand pass phishing page drops ISO file.

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: This ISO file contains a VBScript called qr_thailand_pass.vbs file which begins the malware activity. The content of the vbs file will be in obfuscated form as shown below.

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: Figure 4: Obfuscated content of the qr_thailand_pass.vbs file.

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: After de-obfuscating the VBScript, we can see that the script tries to download a Testavast+denf.txt file from the web hosting site(ec2-34-229-64-131[.]compute-1[.]amazonaws[.]com) and executes the code using the IEX operation with the help of powershell.

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: Figure 5: Deobfuscated content of the qr_thailand_pass.vbs file.

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: The following image shows the content of the Testavast+denf.txt file which contains a code to check if antivirus services ESET, Avast, AVG, or Malwarebytes are running. If any of those services is found, the script modifies the execution flow of the malware to get around the antivirus, and downloads the appropriate files in order to do so. It saves the files related to the antivirus service as untitled.ps1 and executes that powershell script.

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: Figure 6: Checks for AV running service and downloads its related text file accordingly.

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: While execution flows are modified if AV services are found to be present, the final payload (AsyncRAT malware) remains the same.

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: IF AV exists on the host machine

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: Example - Victim Machine runs MalwareBytes AV as a service

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: Here, we have taken a case study of a host with malwarebytes antivirus installed, and will analyze the delivery of an AsyncRAT payload in detail. The following image shows the content of the killd.txt file which downloads the supporting files from web hosting site(ec2-34-229-64-131[.]compute-1[.]amazonaws[.]com)

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: Figure 7: Content of the powershell script present in the Killd.txt file.

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: The image depicts the content of the supporting files like admin.vbs, admin.ps1, 1_powerrun.vbs, 1.bat and 1.ps1 whose main task is to stop the particular AV service to evade detection and to execute the malware attack.

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: admin.vbs - Starts the admin.ps1 powershell script

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: admin.ps1 - Starts the 1_powerrun.vbs script in admin mode

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: 1_powerrun.vbs - runs the 1.bat batch file.

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: 1.bat - runs the 1.ps1 powershell script.

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: Figure 8: Content of the admin.vbs,admin.ps1,1_powerrun.vbs and 1.bat.

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: The final goal of the 1.ps1 powershell script is to stop the MalwareBytes service and add exclusion for the supporting files during the real time scanning as depicted below.

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: Figure 9: Stops the Malwarebytes Antivirus service in Force method.

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: After disabling the running antivirus service, it downloads the AsyncRAT malware from the killd.txt file and starts its malicious activity on the victim's machine.

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: Figure 10: Content of the AsyncRAT payload present in the killd.txt file.

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: If no antivirus services are detected on the victim machine then the code will move to the else as shown below.

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: IF AV does not Exist on the host machine

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: Here the script downloads task.txt, SecurityHealth.exe and SecurityHealth.exe.manifest files from the following domain hxxp://microsoft[.]soundcast[.]me. Then, it executes the task.txt file as untitled.ps1. It also copies the following SecurityHealth[.].exe and SecurityHealth[.]exe[.]manifest files in the startup folder for persistence techniques.

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: Figure 11: If AV not exist, download files from hxxp://microsoft[.]soundcast[.]me/.

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: The following image shows the content of the Task.txt file which creates a scheduled task as GoogleUpdate to execute the dropped SecurityHealth[.]exe file. This naming fools the user and enables the malware to implement its persistence method.

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: Figure 12: Task.txt file uses persistence technique.

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: The securityHealth[.]exe file needs the SecurityHealth[.]exe[.]manifest supporting file to execute its malicious activities.

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: The following image shows the decoded content present in the SecurityHealth[.]exe[.]manifest containing the URL(34[.]71[.]81[.]158/Run/aaa.ps1) to download the malicious powershell script(aaa.ps1).

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: Figure 13: Decoded content present in the SecurityHealth.exe.manifest, downloads aaa.ps1.

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: The downloaded powershell script aaa.ps1 contains the same AyncRAT payload which is present in the killd.txt file(Malwarebytes AV related file).

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: Figure 14: content present in aaa.ps1 file

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: Final payload AsyncRAT malware - Execution Flow

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: The variable $Filc contains the actual AsyncRAT malware payload, which is injected into a legitimate aspnet_compiler.exe file to show it as a genuine file running in background. The following image shows how the process injection is done in detail.

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: Figure 15: AsyncRAT payload process injection in legitimate file(aspnet_compiler.exe).

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: While decoding the variable $Filc, it results in an AsyncRAT malware file that was hidden inside of it. After deobfuscation, converted that into a decimal format and then into ASCII to see the actual executable file (malware payload) as depicted below.

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: Figure 16: Deobfuscated AsyncRAT malware executable.

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: The injected malware payload runs as a legitimate aspnet_compiler.exe process as shown below.

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: Figure 17: Aspnet_compiler is running as a legit file with injected AsyncRAT payload into it.

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: Process Injection - Work Flow

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: We have dissected the deobfuscated AsyncRAT to see how the process injection is accomplished. The following image shows the APIs used for process injection in the Execute method.

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: Figure 18: Content Present in GetMethod- Execute Function - Process injection APIs.

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: The following APIs are also used to inject the malware AsyncRAT into the legitimate file aspnet_compiler.exe file.

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: Figure 19: Content Present in GetType - Order.Yes - Process injection APIs.

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: The payload will also check for the Anti-VM and Anti-debugging techniques to evade detection as follows:

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: Here it checks whether the downloaded malware payload is running in the host or virtual machine, and also uses anti-debugging techniques to hide its actual behavior.

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: Figure 20: Decompiled AsyncRAT file : Anti VM - Anti Debugging techniques.

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: Finally, it steals the networking credentials of the victim and sends the stolen information to the following C&C server (invoice-update[.]myiphost[.]com) as shown below.

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: Figure 21: Decompiled AsyncRAT file - C&C server location.

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: Similar campaign - Delivery using Discord CDN:

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: cdn[.]discordapp[.]com/attachments/921529408060289114/947221997325258772/qr_thailand_pass.zip

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: We have seen several other Thailand Pass organization spam templates that directly deliver the VBScript file that leads to the delivery of the same AsyncRAT malware, as shown below.

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: Figure 22: Thailand pass downloads VBScript file directly.

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: Conclusion:

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: AsyncRAT like other Remote Access Trojans is a powerful malware that plays a significant role in cybercriminal activities. ThreatLabz actively tracks these types of malware attacks to protect our customers from data theft and from other sensitive information being abused by the cybercriminals.

text: About us

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: Zscaler ThreatLabz is a global threat research team with a mission to protect customers from advanced cyberthreats. Made up of more than 100 security experts with decades of experience in tracking threat actors, malware reverse engineering, behavior analytics, and data science, the team operates 24/7 to identify and prevent emerging threats using insights from 300 trillion daily signals from the Zscaler Zero Trust Exchange.

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: Since its inception, ThreatLabz has been tracking the evolution of emerging threat vectors, campaigns, and groups, contributing critical findings and insights on zero-day vulnerabilities, including active IOCs and TTPs for threat actors, malware, and ransomware families, phishing campaigns, and more.

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
chapter_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT
text: ThreatLabz supports industry information sharing and plays an integral role in the development of world-class security solutions at Zscaler. See the latest ThreatLabz threat research on the Zscaler blog.

report_title: Targeted attack on Thailand Pass customers delivers AsyncRAT

text: Security Research Insights and Research
